title: The Culture of Nature: Science, Enlightenment, and Romanticism in Britain 1680-1860
abstractText: A study of the Cultural of Nature; Science, Enlightenment and Romanticism In Britain, 1680-1860, the period spanned by Newtonian science and natural theology, and Darwin's Origin of Species and Ruskin's Modern Painters. Discussing exploration, landscape, flora, fauna, colour and vital forces, connection are traced between works of art, literature, philosophy, and science. It has argued that links between the aesthetic of nature and naturally theology, forged in the era of Newtonian Science, established the basis of a sensibility common to the arts and sciences; its disruption by Romanticism led to a cultural disassociation manifest by the mid-nineteenth century.
